- Given $\displaystyle \rho =\frac{1}{\|W\|}$ and $\displaystyle\frac{1}{\rho^2 }=\sum_{i=1}^N \alpha_i$

so we get $\displaystyle \|W{\|}^2 =\sum_{i=1}^N \alpha_i$

Multiply by $y$ both side ,

$\displaystyle Y^T \|W{\|}^2 =\sum_{i=1}^N \alpha_i y_i$

we know that SVM Dula proble is geven as below :

$\displaystyle\max_{\overrightarrow{\alpha } \ge 0 } \min_{\overrightarrow{w},b }\frac{1}{2}\left\lVert \overrightarrow{w} \right\rVert^2 + \sum_{i = 1}^{n}\alpha_i\left( 1-y_i\left( \overrightarrow{w}\cdot\overrightarrow{x_i}+b \right) \right)$

after taking derivative wrt $b$ we get

we can see that $\displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^N \alpha_i y_i =0$

So our equation $Y^T \|W{\|}^2 =\sum_{i=1}^N \alpha_i y_i$ can now be written as below :

$\displaystyle Y^T \|W{\|}^2 =0$

Now we just need to prove that $Y^T \|W{\|}^2 =0$ which is equivalent to $\frac{1}{\rho^2 }=\sum_{i=1}^N \alpha_i$

$\displaystyle {Y^T \cdot \|W{\|}^2 =\;\left(W^T X+b\right)}^T \sqrt{\left(W^T W\right)^2 }$

$\displaystyle Y^T \cdot \|W{\|}^2 ={\left(W^T X+b\right)}^T \cdot W^T W$

Since $W$ is orthogonal to the margin line so the above dot product becomes zero
$\displaystyle {Y^T \|W{\|}^2 =\left(W^T X+b\right)}^T W^T W=0$

Hence proved :

$\displaystyle \frac{1}{\rho^2 }=\sum_{i=1}^N \alpha_i$ # Answer of Q.2.
